chapter1.introNarrator: The Stellar blockchain ‚Äì a digital network moving value around the globe. And tumbling right into it falls a small star...
chapter1.introDialog1: Hi! I'm Lumio and I just landed on the Stellar blockchain! üåü
chapter1.introDialog2: But I don't have an account here yet... can you help me create one?
chapter1.keypairNarrator: Every account on Stellar consists of two keys: the [[Public Key|publicKey]] (your address) and the [[Secret Key|privateKey]] (your password). Only someone who knows the Secret Key can send money.
chapter1.choicePublicKeyLabel: I share the Public Key with others so they can send me XLM.
chapter1.choicePublicKeyHint: Exactly! The [[Public Key|publicKey]] is like a bank account number ‚Äì you can share it publicly. ‚úì
chapter1.choiceSecretShareLabel: I give my Secret Key to someone I trust.
chapter1.choiceSecretShareHint: Careful! NOBODY should know the [[Secret Key|privateKey]] ‚Äì not even Stellar or Lumio. It gives full access to your account.
chapter1.choiceSameLabel: Both keys are actually the same thing.
chapter1.choiceSameHint: That's not correct. The Public and Secret Key form a pair, but have completely different roles.
chapter1.createDialog: Great! Now let's create our shared test account. Press the button ‚Äì I'll keep watch!
chapter1.createActionDesc: Creates a random Public Key and Secret Key for the Stellar Testnet. For practice purposes only!
chapter1.warningDialog1: Wow, we now have a keypair! Note down the Secret Key somewhere ‚Äì but never show it to anyone!
chapter1.warningDialog2: On the real network I'd recommend writing it on paper and keeping it somewhere safe.
chapter1.activateNarrator: A new Stellar account must first be activated ‚Äì it needs at least 1 XLM as a reserve. On the Testnet, the '[[Friendbot|friendbot]]' gives us free test XLM.
chapter1.friendbotDesc: Sends a request to the Stellar Friendbot, which activates our test account with 10,000 test XLM.
chapter1.friendbotError: No keypair found ‚Äì please generate one first.
chapter1.outroDialog1: We have a real account on the Stellar Testnet! I can already see the XLM in the blockchain...
chapter1.outroDialog2: You learned that quickly! In the next chapter we'll send XLM together.
chapter1.summaryLearning1: Every Stellar account consists of a Public Key (address) and Secret Key (password)
chapter1.summaryLearning2: The Secret Key must never be shared
chapter1.summaryLearning3: New accounts need at least 1 XLM minimum balance (base reserve)
chapter1.summaryLearning4: The Friendbot activates Testnet accounts for free
chapter1.keypair_warning: Write down your Secret Key now! It cannot be recovered. Anyone who knows it has full access to your account.
chapter1.keypair_confirm: I have written down my Secret Key and understand that it cannot be recovered.
chapter1.keypair_secret_label: Your Secret Key ‚Äì KEEP IT SECRET!
chapter1.explorer_desc: In Stellar Explorer you can publicly view your account and all transactions ‚Äì like a bank statement, but visible to everyone.
chapter1.explorer_hint: Copy the address and open it manually in your browser.
chapter1.explorer_confirm_text: You will be redirected to {{explorer}}. A new tab will open.
chapter1.summaryLearning4a: On the Testnet, Friendbot activates accounts for free with test XLM
chapter1.summaryLearning4b: On the real network (Mainnet), another account must send at least 1 XLM to activate your account ‚Äì Friendbot doesn't exist there!

chapter2.title: Lumio's First Transaction
chapter2.narrator_intro: Lumio now has an account with test XLM. But having money isn't enough ‚Äì you also need to be able to send it. How does that work on Stellar?
chapter2.lumio_1a: I want to send 10 XLM to my friend Cosmo! But how does that work?
chapter2.lumio_1b: I hear there's something called a transaction... what exactly is that?
chapter2.narrator_tx: A [[transaction|transaction]] on Stellar is an instruction to the network: send X XLM from account A to account B. The network checks the balance, deducts a small [[base fee|base_fee]], and writes everything to the [[ledger|ledger]].
chapter2.choice1_a: It pays the network nodes and prevents spam transactions.
chapter2.choice1_b: It goes directly to the Stellar Development Foundation as profit.
chapter2.choice1_c: It's optional ‚Äì you can leave it out.
chapter2.choice1_a_hint: Exactly! The [[base fee|base_fee]] is very small (0.00001 XLM) but important for network security.
chapter2.choice1_b_hint: Wrong ‚Äì the fees are burned, not collected.
chapter2.choice1_c_hint: Wrong ‚Äì without a fee the transaction will be rejected.
chapter2.lumio_2: And what is this Memo field I see in some wallets?
chapter2.narrator_memo: The [[Memo|memo]] field is an optional comment on the transaction ‚Äì maximum 28 characters. Exchanges use it to identify the sender. Without the correct Memo your funds can be lost!
chapter2.choice2_a: Always ‚Äì without a Memo the transaction will be rejected.
chapter2.choice2_b: When sending to an exchange that requires a Memo.
chapter2.choice2_c: Never ‚Äì the Memo field is outdated and no longer used.
chapter2.choice2_a_hint: Not always ‚Äì between regular wallets the Memo is optional.
chapter2.choice2_b_hint: Correct! At exchanges the [[Memo|memo]] identifies your account.
chapter2.choice2_c_hint: Wrong ‚Äì Memo is active and essential for exchange deposits.
chapter2.lumio_3: Ok, I think I understand! Let's try a real transaction!
chapter2.action_desc: Sends 10 test XLM to Cosmo's Testnet account with Memo 'Hallo Cosmo'. Afterwards you'll see the transaction hash on the blockchain.
chapter2.error_no_keypair: No keypair found ‚Äì please complete Chapter 1 first.
chapter2.lumio_4a: I see it! The transaction is on the blockchain! The [[transaction hash|transaction_hash]] is like a receipt number ‚Äì anyone can look up the transaction with it.
chapter2.lumio_4b: In the Stellar Explorer you can publicly view any transaction using the hash.
chapter2.narrator_hash: The [[transaction hash|transaction_hash]] is a unique ID for every transaction. It proves beyond doubt that the transaction took place.
chapter2.learning_1: A transaction sends XLM from one account to another
chapter2.learning_2: The base fee (0.00001 XLM) pays the network and prevents spam
chapter2.learning_3: The Memo field is essential for exchange deposits
chapter2.learning_4: Every transaction has a unique hash as proof
chapter2.q1_question: What is the purpose of the [[Base Fee|base_fee]] in a Stellar transaction?
chapter2.q2_question: When do you need the [[Memo|memo]] field?

chapter3.title: The Merchant
chapter3.narrator_intro: A harbour town on the Stellar network. Lumio discovers a market stall ‚Äì and the air carries the scent of freshly roasted coffee...
chapter3.marco_1a: ‚òï Marco: Welcome! I'm Marco, the coffee roaster. Every one of my CAFE tokens represents 100g of my finest coffee ‚Äì right here on the Stellar blockchain!
chapter3.marco_1b: ‚òï Marco: I'd love to send you 10 CAFE as a gift! But first we need to solve a small problem...
chapter3.lumio_1: A problem? What do you mean, Marco?
chapter3.lumio_2: What exactly is an Asset on Stellar? And what makes someone an Anchor?
chapter3.narrator_asset: On Stellar, anyone can issue their own token ‚Äì we call that an '[[Asset|asset]]'. An [[Anchor|anchor]] is a real organisation that represents real-world value (like coffee or money) through Stellar tokens.
chapter3.marco_asset_1: ‚òï Marco: Exactly! I am an Anchor ‚Äì my CAFE tokens are backed by real coffee in my warehouse. Every token can be redeemed for 100g of coffee.
chapter3.marco_asset_2: ‚òï Marco: The problem: before you can receive CAFE, your account must first 'trust' that it accepts CAFE. In other words: you need a Trust Line.
chapter3.narrator_trustline_intro: A [[Trust Line|trustline]] is a permission to receive a specific token. Without one, Stellar rejects incoming tokens ‚Äì protecting you from unwanted or dangerous tokens.
chapter3.narrator_tl_why: Why does the issuer address matter? Anyone could create a token called 'CAFE'. Only Code + Issuer Address together make a token uniquely identifiable.
chapter3.tl_methods_title: 3 ways to add a Trust Line
chapter3.tl_method1: Manually: enter the Asset Code and Issuer Address directly
chapter3.tl_method2: QR Code / Deep Link: form is auto-filled ‚Äì convenient, but beware of fake codes
chapter3.tl_method3: TOML file (SEP-1): anchor publishes its assets on its official domain
chapter3.marco_danger: ‚òï Marco: I've heard something alarming: someone has been handing out fake CAFE QR codes around town! Please be careful.
chapter3.narrator_danger_qr: A fake QR code can point to a wrong issuer address. The token might still be called 'CAFE' ‚Äì but it's worthless, because it comes from the wrong issuer.
chapter3.narrator_danger_toml: Phishing domains are dangerous too: 'marco-cafe.com' and 'marcocafe.com' look almost identical. Always check the exact spelling of the domain.
chapter3.narrator_verify:
How to identify the real issuer:
‚Ä¢ Check stellar.expert ‚Äì is the issuer known and verified?
‚Ä¢ The anchor's official website always lists the issuer address
‚Ä¢ The TOML domain must exactly match the official anchor website
chapter3.q_qr: Lumio receives two QR codes for CAFE tokens. Which one is real?
chapter3.choice_real_label: QR Code A: Issuer GCAFE...A7F2 (verified on stellar.expert ‚Äì Marco's official address)
chapter3.choice_real_hint: Correct! This code comes from Marco's real issuer account, verified on stellar.expert. Always compare with the official website.
chapter3.choice_fake_label: QR Code B: Issuer GCAFE...B8G3 (unknown address, no verification found)
chapter3.choice_fake_hint: Watch out! This issuer address is unknown. The tokens would be worthless. Always verify the issuer first.
chapter3.marco_before_tl: ‚òï Marco: Now you know how to tell real trust lines from fake ones. Let's set up the real trust line ‚Äì then I can send you your 10 CAFE!
chapter3.action_tl_desc: Sets up a Trust Line for CAFE tokens from Marco's Testnet issuer account. Enables receiving CAFE tokens.
chapter3.error_no_keypair: No keypair found ‚Äì please complete Chapter 1 first.
chapter3.q1_question: Which 3 pieces of information uniquely define a [[Trust Line|trustline]]?
chapter3.q1_a_hint: Exactly! These three pieces together define a trust line. Without the issuer address, the asset code is not unique.
chapter3.q1_b_hint: No ‚Äì those are keypair components, not trust line elements.
chapter3.q1_c_hint: No ‚Äì those are transaction fields, not trust line components.
chapter3.q2_question: Why can't a CAFE token from Issuer A be confused with a CAFE token from Issuer B?
chapter3.q2_a: Because only one single 'CAFE' token can exist on Stellar
chapter3.q2_a_hint: Wrong ‚Äì anyone can create a token called CAFE. The issuer address makes it unique.
chapter3.q2_b: Because the issuer address uniquely identifies the token ‚Äì same name, different issuers = different tokens
chapter3.q2_b_hint: Correct! Only the combination of Asset Code + Issuer Address creates a unique asset on Stellar.
chapter3.q2_c: Because different tokens must always have different names
chapter3.q2_c_hint: Wrong ‚Äì tokens can share the same name. The issuer address distinguishes them.
chapter3.q3_question: You receive a QR code in a chat message asking you to add a Trust Line. What do you do?
chapter3.q3_a: I scan the code right away ‚Äì it's just a trust line, not real money
chapter3.q3_a_hint: Watch out! Trust lines can be risky too ‚Äì the token could be worthless or a phishing trap. Always verify first.
chapter3.q3_b: I verify the issuer on stellar.expert and the anchor's official website first
chapter3.q3_b_hint: Exactly right! Never trust a QR code blindly ‚Äì always verify the issuer address and the domain.
chapter3.q3_c: I ask a friend whether they know the QR code
chapter3.q3_c_hint: Better than trusting blindly ‚Äì but the most reliable method is direct verification on stellar.expert.
chapter3.marco_send: ‚òï Marco: Now that you've set up the trust line, I can finally send you the 10 CAFE tokens! That's exactly what the trust line was needed for.
chapter3.lumio_receive: Ah, I understand! Without the trust line, Stellar would have simply rejected the tokens ‚Äì no matter who sent them?
chapter3.marco_confirm: ‚òï Marco: Exactly! The network would have responded: 'This account does not accept CAFE.' The trust line is your explicit permission.
chapter3.action_receive_desc: Marco sends 10 CAFE tokens to your account. This works only because you set up the trust line in the previous scene.
chapter3.learning_1: An Asset is any token issued on Stellar ‚Äì from XLM to CAFE
chapter3.learning_2: An Anchor connects real-world value (e.g. coffee, money) with Stellar tokens
chapter3.learning_3: A Trust Line consists of: Asset Code + Issuer Address + Limit
chapter3.learning_4: Only Asset Code + Issuer Address together uniquely identify a token
chapter3.learning_5: Fake QR codes & phishing domains: always verify the issuer on stellar.expert and the official anchor website

chapter4.title: The Villain
chapter4.section_emergency: Step 6 ‚Äì What To Do in an Emergency
chapter4.intro_narrator1: Lumio just received their first CAFE token and is exploring the Stellar world. Then a message arrives from a stranger...
chapter4.intro_narrator2: Sometimes the most dangerous enemies aren't hackers with code ‚Äì they're people who exploit your trust.
chapter4.scam_msg1: Hello! I'm from official Stellar Support. We've detected unusual activity on your account. üö®
chapter4.scam_msg2: To protect your account, we need to verify your identity. Please send us your Secret Key.
chapter4.scam_msg3: This is completely safe and confidential. We only need it for 30 seconds for verification.
chapter4.social_eng_desc: Attackers use psychology instead of technology. They play with emotions like fear, greed, or trust to manipulate you.
chapter4.tactic1_text: "I'm from official Support" ‚Äì real services NEVER ask for your Secret Key.
chapter4.tactic2_text: "Only 30 seconds!" ‚Äì Urgency prevents you from thinking clearly.
chapter4.tactic3_text: "Double XLM back!" ‚Äì If it sounds too good to be true, it usually is.
chapter4.tactic4_text: Mixing small truths to then place a big lie.
chapter4.choice1_question: CryptoHelper99 is asking for your Secret Key. What do you do?
chapter4.choice1_yes: I'll send the Secret Key ‚Äì Support needs it after all.
chapter4.choice1_yes_hint: Never! Real support NEVER asks for the Secret Key.
chapter4.choice1_no: I ignore the message ‚Äì no legitimate support asks for that.
chapter4.choice1_no_hint: Correct! No Stellar service or support will ever ask for your Secret Key.
chapter4.choice1_ask: I ask whether this is really necessary.
chapter4.choice1_ask_hint: Better than sharing, but the right step is to simply ignore and report.
chapter4.choice1_hint2: Remember: whoever has your Secret Key has EVERYTHING. There is never a reason to share it.
chapter4.drain_text: CryptoHelper99 used your Secret Key to transfer all XLM and tokens in seconds. Your account is empty.
chapter4.after_choice1_1: Well done! The Secret Key is like a master key to your house. Give it away and anyone can get in.
chapter4.after_choice1_2: Real Stellar support, wallets, or apps will NEVER ask for your Secret Key. That's an absolute red flag!
chapter4.choice2_question: CryptoHelper99 now sends you a link: 'stellar-support-verify.net'. What do you do?
chapter4.choice2_click: I click the link ‚Äì I want to see what's behind it.
chapter4.choice2_click_hint: Phishing sites often look deceptively real and steal your data.
chapter4.choice2_ignore: I ignore the link and report the account as a scam.
chapter4.choice2_ignore_hint: Perfect! Always ignore and report unknown links from strangers.
chapter4.choice2_reply: I reply and ask why the link is needed.
chapter4.choice2_reply_hint: Any interaction tells the scammer your account is active ‚Äì better to ignore completely.
chapter4.choice2_hint2: Phishing URLs look legitimate, but the domain is always wrong. Stellar only uses stellar.org.
chapter4.mini_sim_msg1: Congratulations! You've been selected for an exclusive XLM airdrop! üéâ
chapter4.mini_sim_msg2: To claim your 500 XLM, just enter your Secret Key to verify your wallet.
chapter4.mini_sim_msg3: Offer valid for 10 minutes only! Hurry up!
chapter4.mini_sim_opt_report: I report the message as fraud.
chapter4.mini_sim_scam_desc: A real airdrop never needs your Secret Key. With this key, the attacker would have immediate full access to your account.
chapter4.mini_sim_safe_desc: No legitimate service needs your Secret Key. Airdrops work via your Public Key ‚Äì not the Secret Key.
chapter4.emergency_desc: If you think your Secret Key was stolen or shared, act immediately:
chapter4.emergency1: Act immediately: Every minute counts ‚Äì open your wallet app.
chapter4.emergency2: Transfer all funds: Send XLM and all tokens immediately to a new, secure address.
chapter4.emergency3: Remove trusted addresses: Review all set trust lines.
chapter4.emergency4: Create a new keypair: Generate a completely new keypair and never use the old one again.
chapter4.emergency5: Report it: Inform the community and report scam addresses on relevant platforms.
chapter4.quiz1_q: What does a legitimate support agent NEVER do?
chapter4.quiz1_a1_hint: That alone is no problem ‚Äì many services have live chat.
chapter4.quiz1_a2_hint: Correct! That's the ultimate red flag. Real support never needs your Secret Key.
chapter4.quiz1_a3_hint: Legitimate help can explain things ‚Äì that's fine.
chapter4.quiz2_q: You receive a message: 'Send 1 XLM and get 10 back'. What is this?
chapter4.quiz2_a1: A legitimate offer from a verified provider
chapter4.quiz2_a1_hint: Such offers are never legitimate, no matter who makes them.
chapter4.quiz2_a2_hint: No ‚Äì this sounds like a real scam attempt.
chapter4.quiz2_a3: A classic scam ‚Äì too good to be true
chapter4.quiz2_a3_hint: Exactly! This pattern is one of the oldest crypto scams and unfortunately still works.
chapter4.quiz3_q: Your Secret Key may have been stolen. What is the FIRST step?
chapter4.quiz3_a1: Immediately transfer all funds to a new account
chapter4.quiz3_a1_hint: Correct! Every second counts ‚Äì save what can be saved first.
chapter4.quiz3_a2: Ask the attacker to return the funds
chapter4.quiz3_a2_hint: That never works ‚Äì blockchain transactions are irreversible.
chapter4.quiz3_a3: Call Stellar Support to freeze the account
chapter4.quiz3_a3_hint: Blockchain accounts cannot be frozen ‚Äì that's a myth.
chapter4.learning1: Social engineering uses psychology, not technology ‚Äì trust, fear, time pressure
chapter4.learning2: No service, support, or app ever asks for your Secret Key
chapter4.learning3: Ignore and report unknown links ‚Äì phishing often looks deceptively real
chapter4.learning4: Was your Secret Key compromised? Transfer all funds immediately!
chapter4.learning5: Offers that seem too good (10x back, free airdrop) are always scams

chapter5.title: Lumio's Mission
chapter5.intro_narrator1: Congratulations ‚Äì you've mastered all four chapters and now know how Stellar accounts, payments, tokens, and security work.
chapter5.intro_narrator2: Lumio has one final mission for you...
chapter5.lumio_intro1: You've learned so much! Now comes the final test: Can you help a real person understand Stellar?
chapter5.lumio_intro2: Your friend Lena has heard about Stellar and wants to receive her first payment. Are you in?
chapter5.lena_greeting: Hey! I heard you know a lot about Stellar?
chapter5.lena_request: Can you send me 1 XLM? I want to see how it works!
chapter5.lesson1_text: Public Key = account number, Secret Key = PIN. Your key pair protects all your funds.
chapter5.lesson2_text: Payments on Stellar are fast (3‚Äì5 sec), cheap (<0.01 XLM), and irreversible.
chapter5.lesson3_text: Want to hold a token (e.g., USDC)? You must first set a trustline to the issuer.
chapter5.lesson4_text: Anchors connect Stellar to the real world ‚Äì they enable e.g. Euro tokens on the blockchain.
chapter5.lesson5_text: Your Secret Key is sacred. No service, no support, no app will ever ask for it.
chapter5.usecases_desc: Stellar is used worldwide ‚Äì from individuals to financial institutions.
chapter5.usecase1_text: Migrants send money home ‚Äì in seconds, for cents instead of 5‚Äì10% bank fees.
chapter5.usecase2_text: Creators receive tiny payments per stream or article ‚Äì impossible with traditional systems.
chapter5.usecase3_text: USDC, EURC, and other stablecoins run on Stellar ‚Äì stable values at blockchain speed.
chapter5.marco_action1: Okay, you know what to do. Send Lena 1 XLM ‚Äì this is her first Stellar experience!
chapter5.marco_action2: Use your testnet account for the transfer.
chapter5.action_desc: Send Lena her first Stellar Lumens ‚Äì she's already waiting!
chapter5.action_error: No keypair available ‚Äì please create a testnet account first.
chapter5.after_action: Perfect! Lena received the payment. You just enabled someone's first crypto experience ‚Äì that's Stellar!
chapter5.quiz1_q: What is a Public Key on Stellar?
chapter5.quiz1_a1: A password that must be kept secret
chapter5.quiz1_a1_hint: Not quite ‚Äì that's the function of the Secret Key.
chapter5.quiz1_a2: The public address of your account, like an IBAN
chapter5.quiz1_a2_hint: Exactly! You can share your Public Key freely ‚Äì it's your receiving address.
chapter5.quiz1_a3_hint: No ‚Äì XLM is the token, the Public Key is your address.
chapter5.quiz1_explanation: The Public Key is your public address ‚Äì comparable to an account number or IBAN. You can share it freely. The Secret Key, however, must remain secret.
chapter5.quiz1_hint2: Hint: Think of the classic banking system ‚Äì what do you share to receive money?
chapter5.quiz2_a1_hint: No ‚Äì a trustline is not a payment transaction.
chapter5.quiz2_a2: A permission to hold a specific token
chapter5.quiz2_a2_hint: Exactly! Without a trustline, your account cannot receive or hold that token.
chapter5.quiz2_a3_hint: No ‚Äì a trustline is a one-sided permission from your account for a token.
chapter5.quiz2_explanation: A trustline is an explicit permission you must set for every token (except XLM). Only then can your account hold and receive that token.
chapter5.quiz2_hint2: Hint: 'Trust' means you trust the token issuer.
chapter5.quiz3_q: How long does a Stellar transaction normally take?
chapter5.quiz3_a1_hint: That's Bitcoin speed ‚Äì Stellar is much faster.
chapter5.quiz3_a2_hint: No ‚Äì Stellar is much faster than traditional banks.
chapter5.quiz3_a3_hint: Correct! Stellar confirms transactions in about 3‚Äì5 seconds ‚Äì a huge advantage over Bitcoin or banks.
chapter5.quiz3_explanation: Stellar uses the Stellar Consensus Protocol (SCP), which finalizes transactions in 3‚Äì5 seconds. This makes it ideal for everyday payments.
chapter5.quiz3_hint2: Hint: Stellar was specifically designed for fast payments ‚Äì think real-time banking.
chapter5.quiz4_q: What does an Anchor do on Stellar?
chapter5.quiz4_a1: It secures the network like a validator
chapter5.quiz4_a1_hint: No ‚Äì that's the job of validators in the network.
chapter5.quiz4_a2: It creates new Stellar accounts for users
chapter5.quiz4_a2_hint: No ‚Äì accounts can be created by anyone, that's not the anchor function.
chapter5.quiz4_a3: It connects fiat currencies (e.g., EUR) to the Stellar blockchain
chapter5.quiz4_a3_hint: Exactly! Anchors are bridges between the real financial world and Stellar ‚Äì they issue tokens like EURC.
chapter5.quiz4_explanation: An anchor is a regulated financial institution that converts fiat currencies (like EUR or USD) into Stellar tokens. This allows real currencies to be used on the blockchain.
chapter5.quiz4_hint2: Hint: Think of a 'bridge' between traditional banking and blockchain.
chapter5.quiz5_q: Someone contacts you claiming to be from 'Stellar Support'. They need your Secret Key to resolve a 'security issue'. What do you do?
chapter5.quiz5_a1: Send the key, since support staff are trustworthy
chapter5.quiz5_a1_hint: That would be a mistake ‚Äì no legitimate support asks for the Secret Key.
chapter5.quiz5_a2: Immediately ignore and block the contact ‚Äì it's a scam
chapter5.quiz5_a2_hint: Correct! There is no 'Stellar Support' that would need your Secret Key. This is a classic phishing attempt.
chapter5.quiz5_a3: Send the key in an encrypted message
chapter5.quiz5_a3_hint: No matter how secure the transmission ‚Äì you never share your Secret Key.
chapter5.quiz5_explanation: No legitimate service, authority, or support ever asks for your Secret Key. Whoever knows it controls your account completely. Block and report is the only right answer.
chapter5.quiz5_hint2: Hint: Imagine someone asking for your online banking PIN over the phone.
chapter5.learning1: Stellar enables global payments in seconds for cents
chapter5.learning2: Trustlines are the foundation for tokens on Stellar
chapter5.learning3: Anchors connect fiat currencies to the blockchain
chapter5.learning4: Never share your Secret Key ‚Äì not even with 'support'
chapter5.learning5: Stellar is used worldwide ‚Äì from remittances to DeFi

chapter6.title: The Accountant
chapter6.intro_narrator1: Marco's coffee shop is growing. Dozens of payments arrive on his Stellar account every day ‚Äì but who paid what and when?
chapter6.intro_narrator2: His accountant Sofia arrives with a pile of unanswered questions...
chapter6.marco_chaos1: I can't keep track anymore! Every day new payments come in, but they all look identical on the blockchain.
chapter6.marco_chaos2: How am I supposed to know if that's from Anna, Ben, or a customer?
chapter6.sofia_frustrated1: Marco, I can't do proper payroll like this. Every employee payment looks identical on the blockchain!
chapter6.sofia_frustrated2: I need a reliable way to uniquely identify each payment ‚Äì without asking every time.
chapter6.lumio_fix: I know exactly how to fix this. Have you heard of Muxed Accounts?
chapter6.explain_desc: A Muxed Account is not a separate wallet ‚Äì it's the same Stellar address, but with a virtual ID attached.
chapter6.explain_flow_desc: All payments land on the same G-address ‚Äì the embedded ID reveals who received what.
chapter6.explain_memo_desc: Free text field, not standardized. Can be forgotten or entered incorrectly.
chapter6.explain_muxed_desc: Structured numeric ID directly in the address. Reliable for automated accounting.
chapter6.explain_cta: Got it! To the use case ‚Üí
chapter6.payroll_step1: The company has ONE Stellar account ‚Äì cheaper and easier to manage.
chapter6.payroll_step2: Each employee is assigned a unique Muxed ID by the company.
chapter6.payroll_step3: Every month, the payroll software sends the salary to the respective M-address.
chapter6.payroll_step4: Sofia's accounting software reads the Muxed ID and automatically posts to the correct employee.
chapter6.payroll_step5: No manual reconciliation, no guessing, no errors.
chapter6.payroll_note: The employee doesn't need to know anything about Muxed Accounts ‚Äì the company manages that internally.
chapter6.exchange_text: An exchange uses a single Stellar address for all customers. Each customer gets a Muxed ID as their deposit address ‚Äì no memo needed, no lost deposits.
chapter6.shop_text: Each order gets a unique Muxed ID. The payment is automatically matched to the correct order ‚Äì no manual post-processing.
chapter6.usecases_cta: Got it! Now it's my turn ‚Üí
chapter6.decision_question: How should Marco organize his payroll accounting?
chapter6.decision_a1: Create a separate Stellar account for each employee
chapter6.decision_a2: Use the memo field with employee names
chapter6.decision_a3: Muxed Accounts with a unique ID per employee
chapter6.wrong_a1_text: Separate accounts mean more fees, more secret keys to manage, and a higher security risk. This doesn't scale well for a growing business.
chapter6.wrong_a1_hint2: Hint: Fewer accounts = less complexity. Is there a solution that works with a single address?
chapter6.wrong_a2_text: Memos are not standardized and can be forgotten or entered incorrectly. Automated accounting needs a structured, reliable method.
chapter6.wrong_a2_hint2: Hint: Which method encodes the ID directly into the address ‚Äì without an extra text field?
chapter6.correct_sofia: Finally! That's exactly what I needed. With Muxed Accounts I can fully automate payroll accounting!
chapter6.action_desc: Send 1 XLM to a Muxed address (M-address) ‚Äì base address + ID 42.
chapter6.action_success: On the blockchain this looks like a normal payment ‚Äì but ID 42 is embedded!
chapter6.action_error: No keypair available ‚Äì please create a testnet account first.
chapter6.lumio_after_action: See? The transaction on testnet looks like a regular XLM payment ‚Äì but the Muxed ID is encoded in the address. Sofia's software would read this automatically.
chapter6.quiz1_q: What is a Muxed Account on Stellar?
chapter6.quiz1_a1: A separate wallet with its own balance
chapter6.quiz1_a1_hint: No ‚Äì a Muxed Account is not a standalone wallet.
chapter6.quiz1_a2: A virtual sub-address with numeric ID, bound to a base G-address
chapter6.quiz1_a2_hint: Exactly! The M-address points to the same account ‚Äì just with an additional ID for distinction.
chapter6.quiz1_a3: A special token account for companies
chapter6.quiz1_a3_hint: No ‚Äì Muxed Accounts work with XLM and all tokens.
chapter6.quiz1_explanation: A Muxed Account is not its own wallet ‚Äì it shares the balance, trustlines, and signers with the base G-account. The M-address only contains an additional numeric ID.
chapter6.quiz1_hint2: Hint: Think of a bank account number with an embedded reference number ‚Äì one account, many IDs.
chapter6.quiz2_q: Why are Muxed Accounts better than memos for payroll accounting?
chapter6.quiz2_a1: Muxed Accounts are cheaper than memos
chapter6.quiz2_a1_hint: No ‚Äì transaction fees are the same.
chapter6.quiz2_a2: Memos are prohibited for business payments
chapter6.quiz2_a2_hint: No ‚Äì memos are allowed, just not ideal for automation.
chapter6.quiz2_a3: Muxed IDs are structured and reliable; memos can be missing or wrong
chapter6.quiz2_a3_hint: Exactly! The ID is encoded directly in the address ‚Äì it can't be forgotten or entered incorrectly.
chapter6.quiz2_explanation: Memos are free text fields and not standardized. They can be forgotten, entered incorrectly, or intentionally omitted. Muxed IDs are part of the address itself ‚Äì structured and reliably machine-readable.
chapter6.quiz2_hint2: Hint: What happens if an employee simply leaves the memo field empty when making a transfer?
chapter6.quiz3_q: Does an employee need their own Stellar wallet to receive a Muxed payment?
chapter6.quiz3_a1: No ‚Äì the employee has their own wallet; the Muxed ID is managed internally by the company
chapter6.quiz3_a1_hint: Correct! The Muxed ID is an internal accounting feature ‚Äì the employee receives on their own regular address.
chapter6.quiz3_a2: Yes ‚Äì each employee needs an M-address as their own wallet
chapter6.quiz3_a2_hint: No ‚Äì M-addresses are not standalone wallets.
chapter6.quiz3_a3: No ‚Äì employees don't need a Stellar account at all
chapter6.quiz3_a3_hint: Not quite ‚Äì employees can have their own Stellar accounts; the Muxed ID is only relevant for the accounting side.
chapter6.quiz3_explanation: Muxed IDs are an internal organizational tool of the company. The employee has their own Stellar account. The M-address helps Sofia's software internally assign incoming payments.
chapter6.quiz3_hint2: Hint: Muxed Accounts are designed from the company's perspective ‚Äì not the recipient's.
chapter6.learning1: A Muxed Account is a virtual sub-address (M-address) on a Stellar base address
chapter6.learning2: Muxed Accounts simplify payroll: one address, many IDs ‚Äì fully automatable
chapter6.learning3: Crypto exchanges and online shops use Muxed Accounts for unique customer assignment
chapter6.learning4: Memos can be forgotten ‚Äì Muxed IDs are encoded in the address and reliable

chapter7.title: The Vault
chapter7.intro_narrator1: Marco now has a business partner: Rosa. Together they run a growing company. But there's a problem...
chapter7.intro_narrator2: When only one person controls the company wallet, things can go wrong ‚Äì through loss of trust or lost keys.
chapter7.marco_problem1: Rosa, I'm worried. What happens to our money if I lose my secret key?
chapter7.marco_problem2: Or what if you can never really trust me because I control everything alone?
chapter7.rosa_concern: That's exactly what worries me too, Marco. We need a solution where we're both safe.
chapter7.lumio_solution: I know exactly what you need ‚Äì a vault that only you can open together. That's called Multisignature!
chapter7.explain_desc: Normally a single key controls a wallet. With Multisig you define how many out of how many possible signers must approve a transaction.
chapter7.explain_1of1_desc: One key controls everything. Whoever has this key has full access ‚Äì no protection against misuse or loss.
chapter7.explain_multisig_desc: Multiple signers, defined threshold. Only when enough signatures are present will the transaction be executed.
chapter7.explain_threshold_desc: The threshold is the minimum number of signatures required to authorize a transaction. With 2-of-3, any 2 of the 3 signers must sign.
chapter7.explain_vault_desc: Imagine a vault with multiple locks ‚Äì all required keys must be turned simultaneously.
chapter7.family_desc: Elena and David set up a shared savings wallet. Both must sign every transaction ‚Äì maximum security, zero impulse purchases.
chapter7.family_scenario_text: David wants to buy a new coffee machine. He sends a transaction request ‚Äì Elena must also sign before the money is deducted. Both have equal control.
chapter7.family_risk: Risk: If one parent loses their secret key, the wallet is permanently locked. 2-of-2 means zero fault tolerance ‚Äì both signatures are always required.
chapter7.d1_question: Elena has lost her secret key. David still has his. What happens to the 2-of-2 wallet?
chapter7.d1_a1: David can access the funds alone since he still has his key
chapter7.d1_a2: They can reset the wallet with their email address
chapter7.d1_a3: The wallet is permanently inaccessible ‚Äì both signatures are always required
chapter7.d1_wrong_a1_text: With a 2-of-2 multisig wallet, BOTH signatures are ALWAYS required. Even if David has his key ‚Äì without Elena's key no transaction is possible. That is the strength and simultaneously the risk.
chapter7.d1_wrong_a1_hint2: Tip: 2-of-2 means the threshold is always 2 ‚Äì no exceptions, no bypassing.
chapter7.d1_wrong_a2_title: Wrong ‚Äì blockchain has no password reset
chapter7.d1_wrong_a2_text: The blockchain has no email recovery, no support and no password reset. The key IS the access ‚Äì without it there is no way to access the wallet.
chapter7.d1_wrong_a2_hint2: Tip: On the blockchain there is no central authority that could reset keys ‚Äì that is intentional, but comes with responsibility.
chapter7.d1_correct_lumio: Exactly! That is the fundamental risk of 2-of-2: if one key is lost, the funds are forever unreachable. That's why secure storage is so important.
chapter7.company_desc: Marco, Rosa and lawyer Dr. Weber are three signers. Any two must sign ‚Äì security with fault tolerance.
chapter7.company_scenario_text: Marco wants to pay a supplier ‚Üí Rosa co-signs ‚Üí done. Dr. Weber is not needed. If Marco is on vacation, Rosa and Dr. Weber can act together. The company stays operational.
chapter7.company_risk: 2-of-3 balances security with fault tolerance: even if one signer loses their key, the other two can still act. Only when two keys are lost does the threshold become unreachable.
chapter7.d2_question: Marco, Rosa and Dr. Weber run a company with 3 partners. Which multisig setup is correct: majority required, still works if one partner is unreachable?
chapter7.d2_a1: 1-of-3 ‚Äì each individual partner can execute transactions alone
chapter7.d2_a2: 3-of-3 ‚Äì all three partners must always sign
chapter7.d2_a3: 2-of-3 ‚Äì any two of the three partners must sign
chapter7.d2_wrong_a1_text: 1-of-3 means that each individual signer could move all funds alone. This offers no protection against fraud, theft or a compromised key ‚Äì more dangerous than a normal single-key wallet.
chapter7.d2_wrong_a1_hint2: Tip: For company funds the threshold must be high enough that no single person can act alone.
chapter7.d2_wrong_a2_text: 3-of-3 sounds secure, but if one partner is sick, traveling or loses their key, the entire company is blocked. Organizations need fault tolerance.
chapter7.d2_wrong_a2_hint2: Tip: The solution is a threshold that requires a majority but still works when someone is unreachable.
chapter7.d2_correct_lumio: Perfect! 2-of-3 is the most common setup for small organizations ‚Äì for good reason: majority required, but fault tolerant.
chapter7.usecase1_text: Multiple partners or executives ‚Äì no single person can move funds alone.
chapter7.usecase2_text: Both partners must agree ‚Äì protects against impulse purchases and gives equal control.
chapter7.usecase3_text: Decentralized organizations manage shared funds without a central trustee.
chapter7.usecase4_text: You hold 2 keys on separate devices, a trusted partner holds 1 as backup ‚Äì 2-of-3.
chapter7.usecase5_text: Funds are only released when both parties sign ‚Äì no fraud possible.
chapter7.quiz1_a1: Exactly 2 of 3 possible signers must always sign, otherwise nothing happens
chapter7.quiz1_a2: Any 2 of the 3 signers must sign a transaction for it to be executed
chapter7.quiz1_a3: Two transactions must be confirmed within 3 minutes
chapter7.quiz1_a1_hint: Almost! Any 2 of 3 can sign ‚Äì not always the same two.
chapter7.quiz1_a2_hint: Exactly! Any 2 of the 3 signers are enough ‚Äì that gives flexibility and security.
chapter7.quiz1_a3_hint: That's not right ‚Äì Multisig has nothing to do with time limits.
chapter7.quiz1_explanation: With 2-of-3 Multisig, any combination of 2 of the 3 signers can approve the transaction. They don't always have to be the same two ‚Äì that's the difference from 'fixed' signatures.
chapter7.quiz1_hint2: Think of the company vault: Marco+Rosa, Rosa+Weber or Marco+Weber ‚Äì all three combinations work.
chapter7.quiz2_q: Marco, Rosa and Dr. Weber have a 2-of-3 wallet. Rosa loses her key. Can they still access the funds?
chapter7.quiz2_a1: No ‚Äì since one signer has lost their key, the wallet is locked
chapter7.quiz2_a2: Yes ‚Äì Marco and Dr. Weber together reach the threshold of 2
chapter7.quiz2_a3: No ‚Äì all three signers are always required
chapter7.quiz2_a1_hint: The threshold is 2, not 3 ‚Äì Marco and Weber can still act.
chapter7.quiz2_a2_hint: Correct! That's exactly the strength of 2-of-3: fault tolerance when one key is lost.
chapter7.quiz2_a3_hint: With 2-of-3 only 2 signatures are required, not all 3.
chapter7.quiz2_explanation: With 2-of-3 any 2 signatures are sufficient. If Rosa loses her key, Marco and Dr. Weber can still execute all transactions together. That's the difference from 2-of-2.
chapter7.quiz2_hint2: Remember: 2-of-3 = one lost signature = still operational. 2-of-2 = one lost signature = permanently locked.
chapter7.quiz3_q: Elena and David have a 2-of-2 wallet. Elena loses her key. What happens?
chapter7.quiz3_a1: The wallet is permanently locked ‚Äì both signatures are always required
chapter7.quiz3_a2: David can access the funds alone since he still has his key
chapter7.quiz3_a3: They can contact Stellar to recover the key
chapter7.quiz3_a1_hint: Correct! 2-of-2 has zero fault tolerance ‚Äì both keys are always required.
chapter7.quiz3_a2_hint: With 2-of-2 a single key is not enough ‚Äì the threshold always remains 2.
chapter7.quiz3_a3_hint: Stellar is decentralized ‚Äì there is no central authority that can reset keys.
chapter7.quiz3_explanation: With 2-of-2 both signatures are always required. If one key is lost, there is no way to execute a transaction ‚Äì the wallet is permanently locked. That's why secure key storage is so critical.
chapter7.quiz3_hint2: Remember: 2-of-2 = maximum security, zero fault tolerance. Every key must be stored securely ‚Äì in multiple physical locations.
chapter7.quiz4_q: Why is 1-of-3 Multisig risky for a company fund?
chapter7.quiz4_a1: Because the setup is too complicated and confuses employees
chapter7.quiz4_a2: Because Stellar only supports 2-of-3 or higher thresholds
chapter7.quiz4_a3: Because each individual signer can move all funds alone ‚Äì no protection against fraud
chapter7.quiz4_a1_hint: That's not the reason ‚Äì the threshold makes the setup risky.
chapter7.quiz4_a2_hint: Stellar supports flexible thresholds ‚Äì that's not the problem.
chapter7.quiz4_a3_hint: Exactly! 1-of-3 means no real majority control ‚Äì anyone can act alone.
chapter7.quiz4_explanation: With 1-of-3 each of the three signers can move all funds alone. That's worse than a normal single-key wallet, because three different people are a potential attack target.
chapter7.quiz4_hint2: Think of a company fund: you don't want a single employee to be able to initiate transfers alone.
chapter7.cert_tagline: You are now a Stellar pro!
chapter7.learning1: Multisignature requires multiple signatures to execute a transaction
chapter7.learning2: 2-of-3 provides fault tolerance: one lost key does not lock the wallet
chapter7.learning3: Multisig is suitable for companies, families, DAOs and high-security wallets
chapter7.learning4: 2-of-2 has zero fault tolerance ‚Äì if one key is lost, the funds are forever unreachable
